t: Genesis 3
The Temptation and Fall of Man
Now*p the serpent was more cunning than any beast of the field which the Lord*s God had made. And he said to the woman, “Has God indeed said, ‘You shall not eat of every tree of the garden’?”
And*p the woman said to the serpent, “We may eat the fruit of the trees of the garden;
but of the fruit of the tree which is*i in the midst of the garden, God has said, ‘You shall not eat it, nor shall you touch it, lest you die.’”
Then*p the serpent said to the woman, “You will not surely die.
For God knows that in the day you eat of it your eyes will be opened, and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”

So*p when the woman saw that the tree was*i good for food, that it was*i pleasant to the eyes, and a tree desirable to make one*i wise, she took of its fruit and ate. She also gave to her husband with her, and he ate.
Then the eyes of both of them were opened, and they knew that they were*i naked; and they sewed fig leaves together and made themselves coverings.
And*p they heard the sound of the Lord*s God walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and Adam and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the Lord*s God among the trees of the garden.
Then*p the Lord*s God called to Adam and said to him, “Where are*i you?”
So*p he said, “I heard Your voice in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked; and I hid myself.”
And*p He said, “Who told you that you were*i naked? Have you eaten from the tree of which I commanded you that you should not eat?”
Then*p the man said, “The woman whom You gave to*i be*i with me, she gave me of the tree, and I ate.”
And*p the Lord*s God said to the woman, “What is*i this you have done?” The*p woman said, “The serpent deceived me, and I ate.”

So*p the Lord*s God said to the serpent: “Because*pn you have done this, You*ld are*i cursed more than all cattle, And*ld more than every beast of the field; On*ld your belly you shall go, And*ld you shall eat dust All*ld the days of your life.
And*ld I will put enmity Between*ld you and the woman, And*ld between your seed and her Seed; He*ld shall bruise your head, And*ld you shall bruise His heel.”

To*p the woman He said: “I*pn will greatly multiply your sorrow and your conception; In*ld pain you shall bring forth children; Your*ld desire shall*i be*i for your husband, And*ld he shall rule over you.”

Then*p to Adam He said, “Because you have heeded the voice of your wife, and have eaten from the tree of which I commanded you, saying, ‘You shall not eat of it’: “Cursed*pn is*i the ground for your sake; In*ld toil you shall eat of*i it All*ld the days of your life.
Both*ld thorns and thistles it shall bring forth for you, And*ld you shall eat the herb of the field.
In*ld the sweat of your face you shall eat bread Till*ld you return to the ground, For*ld out of it you were taken; For*ld dust you are,*i And*ld to dust you shall return.”
And*p Adam called his wife’s name Eve, because she was the mother of all living.
Also*p for Adam and his wife the Lord*s God made tunics of skin, and clothed them.
Then*p the Lord*s God said, “Behold, the man has become like one of Us, to know good and evil. And now, lest he put out his hand and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live forever”—
therefore the Lord*s God sent him out of the garden of Eden to till the ground from which he was taken.
So He drove out the man; and He placed cherubim at the east of the garden of Eden, and a flaming sword which turned every way, to guard the way to the tree of life.
